qnas.answer: OSHA records (Form 300, 301, and 300A) must be retained for 5 years following the end of the calendar year that the records cover. For example, records for calendar year 2025 must be retained until December 31, 2030. See 29 CFR 1904.33.

qnas.answer: Form 300A (Summary of Work-Related Injuries and Illnesses) must be posted in a conspicuous location from February 1 through April 30 of the year following the year covered by the form. The summary must be posted even if no recordable injuries or illnesses occurred. See 29 CFR 1904.32.

qnas.answer: First aid treatments include: using non-prescription medications at non-prescription strength; administering tetanus immunizations; cleaning, flushing, or soaking wounds; using wound coverings (bandages, Band-Aids, gauze pads) or butterfly bandages/Steri-Strips; using hot or cold therapy; using non-rigid means of support (elastic bandages, wraps); using temporary immobilization devices while transporting; drilling fingernails/toenails to relieve pressure; using eye patches; removing foreign bodies from eye using irrigation or cotton swab; removing splinters with tweezers; using finger guards; using massages; and drinking fluids for relief of heat stress. See 29 CFR 1904.7(a).

An injury or illness is considered work-related if an event or exposure in the work environment either caused or contributed to the resulting condition, or significantly aggravated a pre-existing injury or illness. Work-relatedness is presumed for injuries and illnesses resulting from events or exposures occurring in the work environment, unless a specific exception applies. See 29 CFR 1904.5.
questions: How do I determine if injury is work-related?

qnas.answer: You must record an injury or illness if it results in: death; days away from work; restricted work or transfer to another job; medical treatment beyond first aid; loss of consciousness; or a significant injury or illness diagnosed by a physician or other licensed health care professional. Additionally, you must record any work-related needlestick or sharps injury, work-related case involving medical removal under OSHA standards, work-related hearing loss (standard threshold shift), and work-related tuberculosis. See 29 CFR 1904.7.

The day of the injury or onset of illness is NOT counted as a day away from work. Calendar days include weekends, holidays, and other days the employee would not normally work. Stop counting days away when the employee reaches 180 days or when the employee dies, retires, or leaves employment for reasons unrelated to the injury or illness. See 29 CFR 1904.7(b)(3).

qnas.answer: Partially exempt employers include: establishments in certain low-hazard industries (based on NAICS codes) with 10 or fewer employees; and establishments with 10 or fewer employees at any time during the previous calendar year in designated low-hazard industries. However, all employers must report fatalities, hospitalizations, amputations, and losses of an eye to OSHA, regardless of exemption status. See 29 CFR 1904.1 and 1904.2.

qnas.answer: Medical treatment includes: administering prescription medications (except for first dose for observation); administering non-prescription medications at prescription strength; using wound closing devices such as sutures, staples, or skin adhesives (surgical glue); using rigid means of support (casts, splints); physical therapy or chiropractic treatment; removing foreign bodies from wounds if the procedure is complicated; cutting away dead skin (surgical debridement); and using any device with a rigid stay or other system designed to immobilize parts of the body. See 29 CFR 1904.7(a).

qnas.answer: Privacy concern cases include: injuries or illnesses to intimate body parts or reproductive system; injuries or illnesses resulting from sexual assault; mental illnesses; HIV infection, hepatitis, or tuberculosis; needlestick injuries and cuts from sharp objects contaminated with blood or OPIM; and other illnesses if employee independently requests privacy. For privacy concern cases, do not enter employee name on Form 300 - enter 'privacy case' instead. See 29 CFR 1904.29.

qnas.answer: Employers with 250+ employees in establishments required to keep records must electronically submit Form 300A data, Form 300 data, and Form 301 data annually. Employers with 20-249 employees in certain high-hazard industries must submit Form 300A data only. Submissions are due by March 2 of the year following the calendar year covered. See 29 CFR 1904.41.
